Trial_Design.evidence: Ventilated preterm neonates ( n =898) from 16 centres were randomly assigned to placebo ( n =449) or morphine ( n =449).

Participants.evidence: Ventilated preterm neonates ( n =898) from 16 centres were randomly assigned to placebo ( n =449) or morphine ( n =449).

Intervention.evidence: After an i.v. loading dose (100 µg kg −1 ), morphine infusions [23–26 weeks postmenstrual age (PMA) 10 µg kg −1 h −1 ; 27–29 weeks 20 µg kg −1 h −1 ; and 30–32 weeks 30 µg kg −1 h −1 ] were established for a maximum of 14 days.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Morphine assay and neonatal response to ETT suctioning was measured at 20–28 and 70–76 h after starting the drug infusion and at 10–14 h after discontinuation of the study drug.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Ventilated preterm neonates ( n =898) from 16 centres were randomly assigned to placebo ( n =449) or morphine ( n =449).

Blinding.evidence: Open-label morphine (20–100 µg kg −1 ) was given for pain or agitation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ventilated preterm neonates ( n =898) from 16 centres were randomly assigned to placebo ( n =449) or morphine ( n =449).

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 5119 data points (1598 measured morphine concentrations and 3521 effect measures) were available from 875 neonates for analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: There was no relationship between morphine concentrations (range 0–440 µg litre −1 ) and heart rate changes associated with ETT suctioning or with the Premature Infant Pain Profile.
